name: Swipe: CompTIA Network+ and A+ Network (EN)

meta.source: Generated by AI Assistant (CompTIA N+/A+ focus)

fragen.frage: The Transport Layer of the OSI model is responsible for logical addressing (IP addresses).
fragen.erklaerung: False — The Transport Layer (Layer 4) is responsible for end-to-end communication and flow control. Logical addressing (IP) is the responsibility of the Network Layer (Layer 3).

fragen.frage: A private IPv4 address can be routed directly from the internet.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Private IPv4 addresses (e.g., 192.168.x.x, 10.x.x.x) are intended for local networks only and must not be routed to the internet. NAT (Network Address Translation) is used to translate private addresses into public ones.

fragen.frage: A Cat 6 UTP cable uses special shielding to reduce electromagnetic interference (EMI).
fragen.erklaerung: False — UTP stands for 'Unshielded Twisted Pair'. Shielding is used in STP (Shielded Twisted Pair) cables to reduce EMI, not in UTP.

fragen.frage: The Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) is used to dynamically assign IP addresses to network devices.
fragen.erklaerung: True! DHCP automates the assignment of IP addresses, subnet masks, default gateways, and DNS servers to clients, eliminating the need for manual configuration.

fragen.frage: The Domain Name System (DNS) translates domain names (e.g., google.com) into MAC addresses.
fragen.erklaerung: False — DNS translates domain names into IP addresses. The resolution of IP addresses to MAC addresses on the local network is the job of the Address Resolution Protocol (ARP).

bilder.alt: Diagram of a DNS query flow

fragen.frage: A network switch forwards data packets more efficiently than a hub because it knows the recipient's destination MAC address.
fragen.erklaerung: True! A switch operates at Layer 2 (Data Link Layer) and uses a MAC address table to forward frames specifically to the correct port, instead of sending them to all ports like a hub does.

fragen.frage: UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is a connection-oriented protocol that ensures guaranteed delivery of packets.
fragen.erklaerung: False — UDP is a connectionless protocol. It does not provide guaranteed delivery, error correction, or sequencing, which makes it faster but less reliable than TCP. Ideal for VoIP or online gaming.

fragen.frage: The WLAN standard 802.11ac operates exclusively in the 2.4 GHz frequency band.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 802.11ac (Wi-Fi 5) operates exclusively in the 5 GHz band. The 802.11n (Wi-Fi 4) standard could operate in both the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands.

fragen.frage: The 'ping' command is used to test the reachability of a device on an IP network and to measure round-trip time.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'ping' sends ICMP 'Echo Request' packets to a target and waits for 'Echo Reply' responses to check connectivity and latency.

fragen.frage: A firewall primarily operates at the Physical Layer (Layer 1) of the OSI model.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Traditional firewalls operate mainly at the Network (Layer 3) and Transport (Layer 4) layers by filtering IP addresses and port numbers. Next-Generation Firewalls can even operate at the Application Layer (Layer 7).

fragen.frage: The IPv6 address '::1' is the equivalent of the IPv4 loopback address 127.0.0.1.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The address '::1' is the compressed form of 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 and is used as the loopback address in IPv6 to address the local host.

fragen.frage: Port 80 is used by default for secure, encrypted web communication (HTTPS).
fragen.erklaerung: False — Port 80 is the standard port for unencrypted HTTP. For secure HTTPS, port 443 is used by default.

fragen.frage: A hub is an intelligent network device that reduces collision domains.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A hub is a 'dumb' device that simply forwards incoming signals to all other ports. All devices connected to a hub are in the same collision domain. A switch, however, reduces collision domains, as each port is its own.

fragen.frage: The T568B crimping standard begins with the orange-white/orange wire pair.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The wire order for T568B is: orange-white, orange, green-white, blue, blue-white, green, brown-white, brown. In T568A, the orange and green pairs are swapped.

fragen.frage: NAT (Network Address Translation) is used to convert MAC addresses into IP addresses.
fragen.erklaerung: False — NAT translates private IP addresses into one or more public IP addresses and vice versa. The conversion of IP to MAC addresses is handled by the Address Resolution Protocol (ARP).

fragen.frage: Software as a Service (SaaS) is a cloud model where the customer uses a complete application over the internet without installing it.
fragen.erklaerung: True! With SaaS (e.g., Google Docs, Microsoft 365), the provider takes care of the entire infrastructure, operating system, and application. The customer simply accesses it via a browser or an app.

fragen.frage: A crossover cable is used to connect a PC to a switch.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A straight-through cable (patch cable) is used to connect a PC to a switch. A crossover cable is needed to connect two similar devices directly (e.g., PC to PC or switch to switch), although modern devices often detect this automatically thanks to Auto MDI-X.

fragen.frage: WPA3 is a current security standard for WLANs that offers Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS).
fragen.erklaerung: True! WPA3 significantly improves security over WPA2. By using SAE (Simultaneous Authentication of Equals) instead of PSK, it offers better protection against offline dictionary attacks and ensures Perfect Forward Secrecy.

fragen.frage: The 'ipconfig' command in Windows does not display the MAC address of a network adapter.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The 'ipconfig /all' command displays detailed information, including the 'Physical Address', which corresponds to the adapter's MAC address.

fragen.frage: The Application Layer (Layer 7) in the OSI model is directly responsible for the physical transmission of bits over a cable.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The Application Layer provides the interface for application programs (e.g., browser, email client). The physical transmission of bits is the job of the Physical Layer (Layer 1).

fragen.frage: A router separates broadcast domains, whereas a switch does not.
fragen.erklaerung: True! By default, routers do not forward broadcasts between their interfaces, thus separating broadcast domains. A simple switch forwards broadcasts to all ports, keeping all connected devices in the same broadcast domain.

fragen.frage: APIPA (Automatic Private IP Addressing) assigns an IP address from the 192.168.x.x range if no DHCP server is reachable.
fragen.erklaerung: False — APIPA assigns addresses from the special range 169.254.0.1 to 169.254.255.254. This allows basic communication on a local network without a DHCP server.

fragen.frage: The IMAP (Internet Message Access Protocol) protocol, by default, downloads emails to the user's device and deletes them from the server.
fragen.erklaerung: False — That describes the behavior of POP3. IMAP synchronizes emails with the server, so they are accessible on multiple devices and remain on the server until explicitly deleted.

fragen.frage: A VPN (Virtual Private Network) is used to create a secure, encrypted connection over an insecure network like the internet.
fragen.erklaerung: True! A VPN creates an encrypted 'tunnel' through which data traffic is sent. This protects the data from being snooped on and allows secure remote access to private networks.

fragen.frage: Fiber optic cables are immune to electromagnetic interference (EMI).
fragen.erklaerung: True! Since fiber optic cables transmit data using light pulses instead of electrical signals, they are completely immune to EMI and RFI (Radio Frequency Interference). This makes them ideal for environments with high levels of interference.

fragen.frage: A subnet mask of 255.255.255.0 corresponds to CIDR notation /28.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A subnet mask of 255.255.255.0 means the first 24 bits are for the network, which corresponds to CIDR notation /24. /28 would be 255.255.255.240.

fragen.frage: The 'tracert' (Windows) or 'traceroute' (Linux) command is used to trace the path that packets take to a destination on the network.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The tool sends packets with incrementally increasing Time-to-Live (TTL) and displays the routers ('hops') that respond along the way to the destination. It is very useful for troubleshooting connectivity issues.

fragen.frage: An 'Access Point' connects different IP networks together.
fragen.erklaerung: False — An Access Point (AP) connects wireless devices to a wired network and operates at Layer 2. Connecting different IP networks is the job of a router (Layer 3).

fragen.frage: The TCP 3-way handshake consists of the steps SYN, ACK, FIN.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The 3-way handshake to establish a connection is SYN, SYN/ACK, ACK. The FIN flag is used to terminate a connection.

fragen.frage: In the TCP/IP model, the Internet layer corresponds to the Network layer of the OSI model.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Although the models are not exactly identical, the Internet layer in the TCP/IP model takes on the functions of the Network layer (Layer 3) in the OSI model, especially packet forwarding and logical addressing (IP).

fragen.frage: A device's MAC address is globally unique and is burned into the hardware by the manufacturer.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The MAC (Media Access Control) address is a 48-bit hardware address used to uniquely identify a network adapter on a local network.

fragen.frage: FTP (File Transfer Protocol) is a secure protocol that encrypts all data transfers by default.
fragen.erklaerung: False — FTP transmits data, including passwords, in plain text and is therefore insecure. Secure alternatives are SFTP (SSH File Transfer Protocol) or FTPS (FTP over SSL/TLS).

fragen.frage: The primary purpose of CSMA/CD is collision avoidance in WLAN networks.
fragen.erklaerung: False — CSMA/CD (Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection) is the collision detection method in wired Ethernet networks. In WLANs, CSMA/CA (Collision Avoidance) is used for collision avoidance.

fragen.frage: A 'Default Gateway' is the IP address to which a device sends packets destined for another network.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The default gateway is typically the IP address of the router on the local network that acts as the 'gate' to other networks, like the internet.

fragen.frage: A VLAN (Virtual LAN) allows devices on a physical network to be logically segmented into multiple broadcast domains.
fragen.erklaerung: True! VLANs allow a physical LAN to be segmented into multiple logical LANs. This improves security and efficiency, as broadcasts are only propagated within a VLAN.

fragen.frage: The SMTP protocol is mainly used for retrieving emails from a mail server.
fragen.erklaerung: False — SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is used for sending emails from a client to a server and between servers. POP3 or IMAP are used for retrieving emails.

fragen.frage: A DMZ (Demilitarized Zone) is a highly secure internal network where the most important company servers are located.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A DMZ is a buffer network that lies between the insecure internet and the secure internal network. It houses servers that must be accessible from the internet (e.g., web servers) to protect the internal network.

fragen.frage: The 'netstat' command can be used to display active network connections and open ports on a computer.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'netstat' (Network Statistics) is a useful command-line tool for analyzing network connections, routing tables, and other network statistics.

fragen.frage: PoE (Power over Ethernet) allows devices like IP phones or cameras to be powered over a standard UTP cable.
fragen.erklaerung: True! PoE transmits electrical power along with data over an Ethernet cable. This simplifies the installation of devices in locations without a direct power supply.

fragen.frage: A multimode fiber optic cable is better for very long distances (over 2 km) than a single-mode cable.
fragen.erklaerung: False — It's the other way around. Single-mode fiber has a smaller core and allows light to be transmitted over very long distances (many kilometers). Multimode fiber has a larger core and is intended for shorter distances (up to about 550 m).

fragen.frage: The Physical Layer (Layer 1) of the OSI model deals with the addressing of packets.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The Physical Layer deals with the physical aspects of data transmission like cables, connectors, and electrical signals. The addressing of packets (logical addressing) happens at the Network Layer (Layer 3).

fragen.frage: A proxy server acts as an intermediary for requests from clients seeking resources from other servers.
fragen.erklaerung: True! A proxy can cache content, filter access, and increase client anonymity by making requests on their behalf.

fragen.frage: The WLAN standard 802.11g is backward compatible with 802.11a.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 802.11g (2.4 GHz) is backward compatible with 802.11b (2.4 GHz). Since 802.11a operates in the 5 GHz band, the two standards are not directly compatible.

fragen.frage: A 'Denial of Service' (DoS) attack aims to steal sensitive data.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The main goal of a DoS attack is to make a service or resource unavailable to legitimate users by overwhelming the server with requests. It's about availability, not data theft.

fragen.frage: The IP address 127.0.0.1 is used to send a broadcast to all devices on the local network.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 127.0.0.1 is the loopback address, which always points to the local host. Broadcast addresses typically end in .255 in a Class C network (e.g., 192.168.1.255).

fragen.frage: A Layer 3 switch, unlike a Layer 2 switch, can also perform routing functions between different VLANs.
fragen.erklaerung: True! A Layer 2 switch operates at the Data Link layer and forwards frames based on MAC addresses. A Layer 3 switch can additionally operate at the Network layer and route packets between different subnets or VLANs based on IP addresses.

fragen.frage: The TCP/IP model has more layers than the OSI model.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The OSI model has seven layers, while the classic TCP/IP model has four (Network Access, Internet, Transport, Application). The functionality is grouped differently.

fragen.frage: A patch panel is used to actively supply power to network devices.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A patch panel is a passive distribution panel that serves as a central collection point for network cables. It organizes the cabling but does not supply power to devices. A PoE switch would be responsible for that.

fragen.frage: The 'DORA' process (Discover, Offer, Request, Acknowledge) describes the sequence of a DNS query.
fragen.erklaerung: False — DORA is the mnemonic for the four-step process by which a client obtains an IP address from a DHCP server.

fragen.frage: Port security on a switch can be used to limit the number of MAC addresses allowed on a port.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Port security is a security feature on switches that restricts access to a port based on MAC addresses. It can be configured to allow only specific or a certain number of devices to connect.

fragen.frage: A coaxial cable is a common choice for modern Ethernet installations in office environments.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Coaxial cables were used in early Ethernet networks (10BASE2, 10BASE5) but have now been almost completely replaced by twisted-pair cables (Cat5e, Cat6, etc.). Coax is still used for cable internet and TV.

fragen.frage: The Presentation Layer (Layer 6) of the OSI model is responsible for data encryption and compression.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The Presentation Layer ensures that data is in a format that the Application Layer can understand. It handles data syntax, including encryption, compression, and character set conversion.

fragen.frage: Telnet is a secure protocol for remote access to network devices.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Telnet is insecure because it transmits all data, including credentials, in plain text. SSH (Secure Shell) is the modern, secure standard for remote access.

fragen.frage: An ACL (Access Control List) is a set of rules that filter inbound or outbound traffic on a router or firewall interface.
fragen.erklaerung: True! ACLs are a fundamental tool of network security to permit or deny access based on criteria such as source/destination IP address, protocol, and port number.

fragen.frage: The 802.11ax standard is also known as 'Wi-Fi 6'.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The Wi-Fi Alliance has introduced a simpler naming scheme. 802.11ax is called Wi-Fi 6, 802.11ac is Wi-Fi 5, and 802.11n is Wi-Fi 4.

fragen.frage: An 'nslookup' is used to display a computer's routing table.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'nslookup' is a tool for querying DNS servers to resolve names to IP addresses and vice versa. The routing table is displayed with commands like 'route print' (Windows) or 'route -n' (Linux).

fragen.frage: The MAC address is 64 bits long.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A MAC address is 48 bits long and is usually represented as 12 hexadecimal digits (e.g., 00-1A-2B-3C-4D-5E).

fragen.frage: IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service) provides customers with a complete development environment including an operating system and databases.
fragen.erklaerung: False — That describes PaaS (Platform as a Service). With IaaS, the customer rents the basic IT infrastructure such as virtual machines, storage, and networks and is responsible for installing and managing the operating system and applications themselves.

fragen.frage: A repeater is an intelligent device that analyzes data packets before forwarding them.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A repeater is a Layer 1 device that simply receives a signal and retransmits it regenerated (amplified) to extend the range of a network. It does not analyze any data.

fragen.frage: The HTTPS protocol uses TLS/SSL for communication encryption.
fragen.erklaerung: True! HTTPS stands for 'HTTP Secure' and is essentially the HTTP protocol running over an encrypted TLS (Transport Layer Security) or the obsolete SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) connection.

fragen.frage: A link-local IPv6 address always begins with the prefix FE80::/10.
fragen.erklaerung: True! These addresses are only valid for communication within a single network segment (a link) and are not routed. Every IPv6-enabled interface automatically configures such an address.

fragen.frage: A Man-in-the-Middle attack is a form of phishing.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Although both are types of attacks, phishing is social engineering to trick users into giving up credentials. A Man-in-the-Middle attack actively places itself between two communicating parties to secretly intercept or manipulate traffic.

fragen.frage: RJ-45 is the common connector type for Ethernet twisted-pair cables.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The 8P8C connector, commonly known as RJ-45, is used to connect twisted-pair network cables to computers, switches, and other network devices.

fragen.frage: The Data Link Layer (Layer 2) of the OSI model uses IP addresses for addressing.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Layer 2 uses physical addresses (MAC addresses) for addressing frames within a local network. IP addresses (logical addresses) are used at Layer 3, the Network Layer.

fragen.frage: Channel bonding in WLAN networks combines two channels to increase bandwidth.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Channel bonding, e.g., using 40 MHz instead of 20 MHz channels, is a technique used in standards like 802.11n and newer to double the data throughput by combining adjacent channels.

fragen.frage: A port scanner is a tool used to find physical damage to the ports of a switch.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A port scanner is a software tool that checks a host or a network for open TCP and UDP ports. This is often used to identify potential security vulnerabilities.

fragen.frage: DHCP snooping is a security feature to prevent the spread of viruses in a network.
fragen.erklaerung: False — DHCP snooping is a security feature on switches that blocks malicious (rogue) DHCP servers on the network. It ensures that clients only receive IP addresses from authorized DHCP servers.

fragen.frage: A 'hybrid cloud' model combines the use of public and private cloud services.
fragen.erklaerung: True! A hybrid cloud allows companies to keep sensitive data in a private cloud while simultaneously leveraging the scalability and cost advantages of a public cloud for less critical applications.

fragen.frage: The 'Spanning Tree Protocol' (STP) is used to find the fastest route in a routed network.
fragen.erklaerung: False — STP is used in switched networks to prevent loops by blocking redundant paths. Routing protocols like OSPF or EIGRP are responsible for finding the fastest path in routed networks.

fragen.frage: The public IPv4 address 192.0.2.1 is reserved for testing and documentation purposes.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The address block 192.0.2.0/24 (TEST-NET-1) is specifically reserved to be used in documentation and examples without conflicting with real public addresses.

fragen.frage: A 'frame' is the Protocol Data Unit (PDU) of the Network Layer (Layer 3).
fragen.erklaerung: False — The PDU of the Network Layer is the 'packet'. The 'frame' is the PDU of the Data Link Layer (Layer 2).

fragen.frage: The main difference between single-mode and multi-mode fiber is the color of the jacket.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Although the colors are often standardized (yellow for single-mode, orange/aqua for multi-mode), the main difference is the diameter of the fiber core. Single-mode has a much thinner core that allows only one light ray (mode) to pass through.

fragen.frage: SSH (Secure Shell) uses port 22 by default.
fragen.erklaerung: True! TCP port 22 is the default port reserved for SSH connections, enabling secure, encrypted remote command-line access.

fragen.frage: A 'phishing' attack is an attempt to obtain sensitive information such as passwords through fake emails or websites.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Phishing is a form of social engineering where attackers impersonate a trustworthy entity to trick victims into revealing confidential data.

fragen.frage: The WLAN standard 802.11b has a higher maximum data throughput than 802.11g.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 802.11b has a maximum theoretical throughput of 11 Mbps, while the newer 802.11g standard reaches up to 54 Mbps. Both operate in the 2.4 GHz band.

fragen.frage: A DNS record of type 'AAAA' is used to resolve a domain name to an IPv4 address.
fragen.erklaerung: False — An 'AAAA' (Quad-A) record is used to resolve a domain name to an IPv6 address. An 'A' record is used for IPv4 addresses.

fragen.frage: The 'ifconfig' command is the standard tool for network configuration on all modern Windows versions.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'ifconfig' is the traditional tool for Unix and Linux systems (though it is often replaced by 'ip'). The standard tool on Windows is 'ipconfig'.

fragen.frage: A 'router on a stick' is a configuration where a single router port serves multiple VLANs via a trunk link.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This method is used to enable inter-VLAN routing with only one physical interface on the router. The link between the router and the switch is configured as a trunk that carries traffic for multiple VLANs.

fragen.frage: The Session Layer (Layer 5) of the OSI model is responsible for managing dialogues between computers.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The Session Layer establishes, manages, and terminates communication sessions between applications. It handles dialogue control and synchronization.

fragen.frage: A 'community cloud' model is a cloud service accessible to the general public.
fragen.erklaerung: False — That describes a 'public cloud'. A 'community cloud' is shared and used by several organizations with common interests (e.g., security requirements, industry affiliation).

fragen.frage: A crossover cable can be created by wiring one end according to T568A and the other end according to T568B.
fragen.erklaerung: True! By using different standards on the two ends, the transmit and receive pairs are crossed, which is necessary for the direct connection of two similar devices.

fragen.frage: The ARP cache stores a mapping of domain names to IP addresses.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The ARP cache stores a mapping of IP addresses to MAC addresses for devices on the local network. The DNS cache stores the mapping of domain names to IP addresses.

fragen.frage: TCP uses window size for flow control.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The receiver informs the sender via the window size how much data it can receive before an acknowledgment (ACK) is sent. This prevents the sender from overwhelming the receiver.

fragen.frage: An Intrusion Prevention System (IPS), unlike an IDS, can not only detect but also actively block suspicious network traffic.
fragen.erklaerung: True! An Intrusion Detection System (IDS) detects attacks and alerts, while an Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) sits 'inline' in the traffic and has the ability to immediately discard malicious packets.

fragen.frage: The main advantage of 802.11n over 802.11g was the introduction of WPA2 encryption.
fragen.erklaerung: False — WPA2 was introduced before 802.11n. The main advantages of 802.11n (Wi-Fi 4) were significantly higher data throughput through techniques like MIMO (Multiple Input, Multiple Output) and channel bonding.

fragen.frage: The loopback address is used to test the functionality of the TCP/IP stack on the local device.
fragen.erklaerung: True! A ping to 127.0.0.1 (or ::1) never leaves the local computer. A successful response confirms that the network hardware and the TCP/IP protocol stack are functioning correctly.

fragen.frage: A unicast packet is intended for exactly one recipient on the network.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Unicast is the most common form of network communication and describes a one-to-one connection between a sender and a receiver.

fragen.frage: A DNS MX (Mail Exchanger) record specifies the IP address of a web server.
fragen.erklaerung: False — An MX record specifies the responsible mail server(s) for a domain. An A or AAAA record is used for the IP address of a web server.

fragen.frage: OSI Layer 2 is also known as the Data Link Layer.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This layer is responsible for the error-free transmission of data (frames) between two directly connected nodes in a network and uses MAC addresses for addressing.

fragen.frage: A bridge is a modern network device that is more intelligent than a router.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A bridge is an older device that connects two network segments at Layer 2. A switch is essentially a multi-port bridge. A router is more intelligent because it operates at Layer 3 and can make path decisions based on IP addresses.

fragen.frage: MIMO (Multiple Input, Multiple Output) is a WLAN technology that uses multiple antennas for sending and receiving to increase performance.
fragen.erklaerung: True! MIMO is a key feature of modern WLAN standards like 802.11n (Wi-Fi 4) and newer. It significantly improves throughput and reliability by transmitting multiple data streams simultaneously.

fragen.frage: The 'arp -a' command is used to add new static ARP entries.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The 'arp -a' command is used to display the current content of the ARP cache. To add a static entry, one would use 'arp -s [IP address] [MAC address]'.

fragen.frage: When troubleshooting a network, the top-down approach dictates that you should always start at the Application Layer (Layer 7).
fragen.erklaerung: True! The top-down approach starts at the Application Layer and works its way down the OSI model. The bottom-up approach starts at the Physical Layer (Layer 1). Both are valid methods.

fragen.frage: A public cloud is operated by a single company for its exclusive use.
fragen.erklaerung: False — That describes a private cloud. A public cloud is operated by a third-party provider (e.g., AWS, Google, Microsoft) and its resources are made available to the general public over the internet.

fragen.frage: Attenuation in network cables is a desirable effect that improves signal quality.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Attenuation is the loss of signal strength over a distance. It is an undesirable effect that limits the maximum length of a cable before the signal becomes unreadable.

fragen.frage: A 'stateful firewall' monitors the state of active connections and makes decisions based on the context of the traffic.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Unlike a 'stateless firewall' which inspects each packet in isolation, a stateful firewall can determine if an incoming packet is part of an existing, legitimate connection, which significantly increases security.

fragen.frage: The primary purpose of the Session Layer (Layer 5) is data formatting.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Data formatting (e.g., encryption, compression) is the job of the Presentation Layer (Layer 6). The Session Layer (Layer 5) is responsible for managing dialogues and sessions.

fragen.frage: DNSSEC is an extension that digitally signs DNS responses to ensure their authenticity.
fragen.erklaerung: True! DNSSEC (Domain Name System Security Extensions) was developed to provide protection against attacks like DNS spoofing by ensuring that the received DNS data comes from the authoritative source and has not been tampered with.

fragen.frage: A 'default gateway' is not needed on a network if all devices are on the same subnet and do not communicate with external networks.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The default gateway (usually a router) is only needed when a device needs to communicate with a host outside of its own local subnet.

fragen.frage: The SSID (Service Set Identifier) is the password for a WLAN network.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The SSID is the name of the WLAN network. The password is known as the Pre-Shared Key (PSK) or passphrase.
